item.title: 7 Children From an Orthodox Jewish Family Die in Brooklyn Fire
item.description: A fire that ripped through the home of an Orthodox Jewish family, trapping the children — ages 5 to 16 — in their bedrooms, was sparked by a malfunctioning hot plate, officials said.
item.dc:creator: NATE SCHWEBER and BENJAMIN MUELLER

item.title: ISIS Urges Sympathizers to Kill U.S. Service Members It Identifies on Website
item.description: The group posted a list of names, photos and addresses of 100 service members who they said had participated in efforts to defeat the militant group.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and HELENE COOPER

item.title: Under Health Care Act, Many Tax Filers Are Discovering Costly Complications
item.description: Under the Affordable Care Act, people who remained uninsured last year must either pay a penalty with their taxes or claim an exemption.
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.dc:creator: ABBY GOODNOUGH
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen for The New York Times
item.media:description: J.C. Ciesielski, 34, prepared his taxes with Richard Matthews, an accountant at Just Harvest Tax Center, in Pittsburgh this month. Mr. Ciesielski had to repay part of his health care subsidy after not adjusting his income.

item.title: Chuck Bednarik, Eagles’ Man of Concrete, Dies at 89
item.description: Bednarik, the Philadelphia Eagles’ Hall of Fame center and linebacker, was one of the last N.F.L. players to commonly play on both offense and defense.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD GOLDSTEIN
item.media:description: Chuck Bednarik with Green Bay’s Paul Hornung (5) and Jim Taylor (31) after the Eagles won the N.F.L. championship game.

item.title: From Minneapolis to ISIS: An American’s Path to Jihad
item.description: The chilling progression of a Minnesota man suggests that the Islamic State may rely on recruiters inside the United States and shows how hard it is to predict who will be swept away by ideological fervor.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: Abdi Nur, right, posted a photo online from Syria. A friend, Abdullahi Yusuf, left, was stopped as he tried to depart. Top, an image of Western passports put up by a Twitter user who says she is an American with the Islamic State.

item.title: Izola Ware Curry, Who Stabbed King in 1958, Dies at 98
item.description: In 1958, Ms. Curry stabbed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. at a Harlem book signing — an episode that a decade later would become a rhetorical touchstone in the last oration of his life.
item.category: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People
item.dc:creator: MARGALIT FOX

item.title: Panic at New Orleans Airport as Police Shoot Man Who Attacked T.S.A. Officers
item.description: A man attacked security officers at New Orleans airport with wasp spray and a machete before being shot by a sheriff’s deputy stationed at the airport, officials said.
item.dc:creator: CAMPBELL ROBERTSON and LIAM STACK

item.title: From Minneapolis to ISIS: An American’s Path to Jihad
item.description: The chilling progression of a Minnesota man suggests that the Islamic State may rely on recruiters inside the United States and shows how hard it is to predict who will be swept away by ideological fervor.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: Abdi Nur, right, posted a photo online from Syria. A friend, Abdullahi Yusuf, left, was arrested trying to join him. Top, an image of Western passports put up by a Twitter user who says she is an American with the Islamic State.

item.title: Kerry Pushes Iran Nuclear Deal Timetable Amid Differences With France
item.description: The secretary of state said negotiators should stick to their goal of completing an initial accord limiting Iran’s nuclear program by the end of March.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry in Lausanne, Switzerland, on Saturday.

item.title: A Luxury Liner Docks, and the Countdown’s On
item.description: The profitability of today’s giant cruise ships depends on a tightly choreographed routine that’s part Nascar pit stop, part Noah’s Ark.
item.dc:creator: JAD MOUAWAD

item.title: New York Fire Department: 7 Children Die in Brooklyn Fire
item.description: Fire tore through a Brooklyn residence early Saturday, killing seven children and leaving two other people in critical condition, authorities said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Serena Williams Withdraws From Indian Wells With Knee Injury
item.description: Williams withdrew before her semifinal at the BNP Paribas Open on Friday night with a right knee injury, 14 years after her sister, Venus, did the same thing and fans reacted angrily, driving Serena to boycott the tournament.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:credit: Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Serena Williams during her quarterfinal match against Timea Bacsinszky at Indian Wells on Wednesday.

item.title: A Life Upended After an IV Glucose Treatment Popular Among Asian Immigrants
item.description: Two years since undergoing amputations after receiving a treatment known as a ringer, Myung Hwa Jang has become comfortable with daily routines like climbing into bed and grocery shopping.
item.dc:creator: JIHA HAM
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Myung Hwa Jang at the National Rehabilitation Center in Seoul, South Korea. Ms. Jang's legs were partially amputated after an infection she attributes to a glucose injection.

item.title: Philadelphia Commissioner Steps Into Fray Between Police and Public
item.description: Even in a city with a black chief of police, relations between law enforcement and the public are strained.
item.dc:creator: TIMOTHY WILLIAMS
item.media:credit: Steven M. Falk/Philadelphia Inquirer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters threw chairs during a town hall meeting in Philadelphia that was attended by Charles Ramsey, the police commissioner.

item.title: Notre Dame Rides a Streak With Shoes Like Highlighters
item.description: Those hues of the Irish’s sneakers have streaked across basketball courts over the last two and a half weeks, offending traditionalists, clashing with the team’s gold jerseys and blinding viewers at home.
item.dc:creator: BEN SHPIGEL
item.media:description: Notre Dame’s Pat Connaughton, recovering a ball Thursday, is one of the Irish players wearing colorful shoes.

item.title: Officials Urge Patience as Hanging of Black Man Is Investigated in Mississippi
item.description: Two federal law enforcement officials suggested that the hanging of Otis James Byrd might have been a suicide, but other officials said it was too early draw conclusions.
item.dc:creator: CAMPBELL ROBERTSON and RICHARD FAUSSET
item.media:credit: Josh Edwards/The Vicksburg Post, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Claiborne County officials prepared to leave a home in Port Gibson, Miss., on Thursday as they investigated a hanging.

item.title: Judge Rules Wisconsin Abortion Restriction Is Unconstitutional
item.description: A federal judge on Friday struck down a state law requiring doctors performing abortions to get hospital admitting privileges.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Suicide Attacks at Mosques in Yemen Kill More Than 130
item.description: An affiliate of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attacks at two Zaydi Shiite mosques in Sana, the capital.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED ALI KALFOOD KAREEM FAHIM and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Victims of mosque bombings in the Yemeni capital were evacuated on Friday. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.

item.title: U.S. May Stay in Afghanistan After '16
item.description: President Obama is considering leaving American troops in Afghanistan after he leaves office, instead of only a small force to protect the embassy in Kabul, a White House official said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: White House Antagonism Toward Netanyahu Grows
item.description: Despite Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s election victory, he is still out of the good graces of the Obama administration, which has had to reassess its policy toward Israel.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
